children.text: Are you considering freelancing or already navigating the freelance world but struggling to determine your hourly rate? You're not alone. Setting the right hourly rate is a crucial step in building a successful freelance career. It ensures you're fairly compensated for your expertise and the value you deliver. Use this calculator to estimate your

Freelancing isn't just about doing the work, it's about running a business. You're not only the talent but also the admin, marketer, accountant and salesperson. A general rule of thumb is to assume that around 75% of your working day will be spent on billable tasks. This means if you have an 8-hour workday, you can realistically estimate 6 billable hours. You also need to account for vacation, holidays, and sick days when you won't earn but still have expenses.
Decipad understands time, so you can modify the units as per day, per week, per year, per month by just typing.
Based on the below inputs, you will have
Now, let's calculate the costs of running your freelance business, including covering your personal expenses to support your desired lifestyle. This forms your
requirement. Additionally, tally up all your
, such as marketing, administrative costs, tools, etc.

You won't pocket 100% of your income. As a freelancer, you're responsible for paying your own taxes and you may incur fees related to invoicing or payment processing. It's important to account for income related expenses.
To ensure your earnings cover your expenses, let's work with the assumption that your total income is equal to your costs:
. If you prefer to use a different estimate for income, enter it below in the 'Adjusted Income' field. Otherwise, leave it blank.
Your estimated taxes and fees are:
Based on your estimated working hours, expenses and taxes and fees your break even hourly rate is
To estimate your optimal rate, you may want to include a margin above your break even rate. Your margin might consider your skill level, location or competitors. At a
your time isn't the only driver of value

. While hourly rates are a straightforward way to bill clients, they don't always reflect the true value of your work. For a high value project, you may want to charge a premium for your time or include a retainer in addition to an hourly rate. Consider the value you provide, your experience and expertise. Use the below table to add/edit premiums for different packages and services:
That's a Wrap! Let us know if you need help customizing this model to your needs.

Remember that finding the right balance between competitive pricing and fair compensation can take some trial and error. Regularly review your rates and adjust them as needed to reflect changes in your skills, market conditions, and client expectations.
